title: Are renewable energy technologies really green? - Quora

response.answer_text: No easy answer as there are several measures of greenness. Hydro energy has an impact on river systems that needs to be at least partially mitigated. Tidal energy can be harvested, but again other considerations like impacts on fisheries and other users of the coastal shoreline are relevant. Wind energy is relatively okay in terms of its environmental impacts, and increasingly environmental cost of production. It does however have a tendency to impact on migrating birds if turbines are located on migration routes. Bio fuel production uses up either food growing land and water, which is increasingly scarce or impacts natural habitat and biodiversity. Biofuel is therefore a niche solution, but can be relatively cheap, efficient and energy rich - particularly important for transport, where at present there are few alternative fuels/ energy sources. Energy from waste is an obvious solution for stand alone small industrial operations and urban centres, particularly if they are already producing methane. Use of solar or other energy source to generate hydrogen fuel could be a low impact solution that would significantly lower carbon emissions as well. Again, the issue is finding an energy source to generate energy - work in progress. Old generation nuclear power plants are relatively energy efficient, but have a big disposal problem so their lifetime environmental cost is high, including their initial construction cost in terms of carbon emissions. New generation plants based on thorium are not yet in production and we aren’t yet sure of the initial carbon emission cost of construction. Use of deep earth temperature differentials on a heat pump principle has real potential for being both efficient and very low in carbon emissions. Ordinary geothermal energy production is relatively cheap and efficient, but found in few places and it has limits on how much a field can be utilised - it suits small population areas like Iceland. Alternatives to fossil fuels as a rule cost in terms of the carbon emission debt when creating the generating and storage equipment. But in general the environmental cost decreases over time as the materials and methods of producing equipment become more efficient and the methods of energy concentration and distribution become more and more efficient, as is occurring with solar at present. The least impact is generated by replacing existing plant and equipment over time as it wears out with much more efficient plant and equipment that uses less energy - likewise the use of insulation in housing. Of course older plant and equipment should ideally be reused or recycled if that is reasonably efficient in energy terms - often it isn’t yet. Another relatively efficient means of gaining more useful energy is improving transmissions to minimize transition losses. This goes hand in hand with having better storage systems like battery banks. Unfortunately batteries are expensive in their environmental impacts. Reducing the amount of rare metals in batteries may improve the overall cost/benefit ratio over time. The main issues with any source of energy is that it costs to extract and use. Even though we think we have sophisticated technology we have a long way to go before we have low impact, high efficiency, low carbon energy sources available when we need them for the populations we have produced. If you want more information on technical efficiencies you might need to go to specialist websites and focus on phrases like energy efficiency and carbon emission sources. The whole field is an expanding one and work in progress. Taking away some of the advantages given to fossil fuel emitters may force the pace along a bit and concentrate everyone’s minds a little more to encourage innovation.

There are always trade-offs. The main reason that most people are interested in alternate energy is to avoid generating byproducts that cause global warming. To find out if a method is really “green”, one must have a complete picture of everything that goes into producing it, and everything that comes out, including unfortunate disadvantages that advocates don't like to mention. I carefully read any analyses that are critical of a method- that is where you can often hear about problems. Regular energy production using unsustainable resources may still work for a long time, but will eventually be depleted and then we will have to switch to some other methods. One can argue about overall costs and desirability, but the truth will out when someone actually uses those methods. For example, there enough wind farms that we can now begin to see how practical they are. The whole alternate energy situation is developing very rapidly. Experience and continued new developments will have critical influences on just how green the technology is.

Are renewable energy technologies really green? Of course it is a mixed bag, but comparing to other technologies - absolutely yes. For hydro energy dams and plants have to be built, often it implies some flooding of some area and some earth work to make the river flow in another path. Solar panels have to be built, installed and and the end of their usable life partially recycled and partially disposed. Wind turbines have to be built - and they also won’t last forever. But comparing to everything else - yes, they are green. None of those has any emissions. No CO2, not anything else. Even comparing to nuclear energy which (as we all know) creates nuclear waste - which nobody wants. NIMBY syndrome. Wind turbines have some opposition too, but not nearly as much as nuclear power plants. So are they green? Well let’s put it that way - they are a lot greener than any alternative.

Not most of them, no. Most “renewable” energy technologies produce no emissions while they are being used. However, to see whether something is truly “green” or not, you have to carefully observe its entire lifecycle — including the entire manufacturing process, typical “costs” of installation, and disposal costs. However, the most important question is: who is it that is telling you that a particular product is green? It’s the corporations that manufacture the product. Are they telling the whole truth? Probably not. It seems crazy to me that the part of the public that tends to distrust corporations the most is also the part of the public that is most gullible when it comes to believing in green energy technologies.

In that “green” is a political term and to a lesser extent so is “renewable”, yes, almost by definition. Or, if we think of “green” as simply meaning good for the environment and for humanity, which leaves out much of hydro, and “renewable”as simply meaning there’s no danger of the resource ever running out, which includes the better nukes, then yes, again renewable is green. But if we try to mix politics and reality, it gets rather confusing, as some politically green technologies aren’t really renewable, and some politically non-renewable technologies are really very green indeed.

As technologies which do not consume fossil fuel, they should be, but it is not totally clear cut. Take nuclear fission. It emits no carbon dioxide during its operation but there a lot of carbon emissions associated with its construction and decommissioning, the processing of its fuel and the associated transport of that fuel and of the processing and transport of its waste. Then there is the problem with the radioactivity of that waste. You could argue that nuclear fission is not renewable, since uranium ore is consumed. But the same arguments would apply to nuclear fusion, apart from the radioactivity of its waste.

Yes and no. On an absolute basis nothing is purely “Green”. On a relative basis, compared to coal as megabad - globally - but even worse for the local environment and people living nearby - and even natural gas - wind and solar are an order of magnitude “greener”. They are also a bit more labor intensive and thus contribute to a higher wage class of jobs than typical energy production jobs.
